results.title: New, newer, newest
results.creator_credit: Channel Four and WNET (Television station : New York, N.Y.)
results.brief_description:
Episode number 18 of Series “Art of the western world”.
For 200 years, the Western world has been coming to terms with industrialisation and with far reaching social, political and economic change. It has yet to settle with the pluralistic view of cultural history which has resulted from these changes. Beneath a blitz of information about the past, including the quite recent past, Western culture has fractured. This episode examines Conceptualism and the effects on modern day architecture.

results.title: New Zealand: the land and it's people
results.brief_description: Classroom film depicting a trip through New Zealand’s North and South Islands with scenes showing that this country of mountains, forests and grasslands is a modern nation whose people share many of the customs of all English-speaking people. Includes views of the livestock and dairying industries, the busy port cities, and the activities and recreation of the people of both European and Maori ancestry.

results.title: New Zealand: Islands of Adventure
results.creator_credit: Ceidrik Heward, Peter Newport and International Video Network
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Video visits”.
Discover why New Zealanders call it “God’s own country”. The awe-inspiring scenery of the North and South Islands with subtropical beaches, mountain glaciers, steaming geysers and rich farmlands, make this country a natural wonderland. Meet New Zealand’s original inhabitants, the Maoris, who arrived by canoe from Polynesia more than 1,000 years ago. Fly over the snow-capped peaks of Mount Cook and ferry across the beautiful and remote Mallborough Sounds. Enjoy the breathtaking scenery along Milford Track and visit Auckland, the largest city and a boat owner’s paradise.

results.title: New Zealand Weekly Review. No. 293. Culture: music and children
results.brief_description: Introduces the New Zealand National Symphony Orchestra and the special children’s concerts given to stimulate an interest in music. At one performance, students hear the Orchestra’s rendition of “Fingal’s Cave Overture” and “Handel in the Strand” followed by a short explanation by conductor Anderson Tyers.
